description: The pancreatic islets or islets of Langerhans are the regions of the pancreas that contain its endocrine cells, discovered in 1869 by German pathological anatomist Paul Langerhans. The pancreatic islets constitute 1–2% of the pancreas volume and receive 10–15% of its blood flow. The pancreatic islets are arranged in density routes throughout the human pancreas, and are important in the metabolism of glucose.
ai_overview: Regions of pancreas containing endocrine cells, discovered by Paul Langerhans in 1869
Constitute 1-2% of pancreas volume but receive 10-15% of blood flow
Arranged throughout pancreas and play key role in glucose metabolism

description: Guanine nucleotide exchange factors (GEFs) are proteins or protein domains that activate monomeric GTPases by stimulating the release of guanosine diphosphate (GDP) to allow binding of guanosine triphosphate (GTP). A variety of unrelated structural domains have been shown to exhibit guanine nucleotide exchange activity. Some GEFs can activate multiple GTPases while others are specific to a single GTPase.
ai_overview: Proteins that activate GTPases by stimulating GDP release to allow GTP binding
Various unrelated structural domains can exhibit GEF activity
Can be specific to single GTPase or activate multiple GTPases

description: GTPase-activating proteins or GTPase-accelerating proteins (GAPs) are a family of regulatory proteins whose members can bind to activated G proteins and stimulate their GTPase activity, with the result of terminating the signaling event. GAPs are also known as RGS protein, or RGS proteins, and these proteins are crucial in controlling the activity of G proteins. Regulation of G proteins is important because these proteins are involved in a variety of important cellular processes. The large G proteins, for example, are involved in transduction of signaling from the G protein-coupled receptor for a variety of signaling processes like hormonal signaling, and small G proteins are involved in processes like cellular trafficking and cell cycling. GAP's role in this function is to turn the G protein's activity off. In this sense, GAPs function is opposite to that of guanine nucleotide exchange factors (GEFs), which serve to enhance G protein signaling.
ai_overview: Regulatory proteins that bind activated G proteins and stimulate their GTPase activity to terminate signaling
Also known as RGS proteins; function opposite to GEFs by turning off G protein activity
Control G proteins involved in hormonal signaling, cellular trafficking, and cell cycling

description: GTPases are a large family of hydrolase enzymes that bind to the nucleotide guanosine triphosphate (GTP) and hydrolyze it to guanosine diphosphate (GDP). The GTP binding and hydrolysis takes place in the highly conserved P-loop "G domain", a protein domain common to many GTPases.
ai_overview: Large enzyme family that binds GTP and hydrolyzes it to GDP
GTP binding and hydrolysis occurs in conserved P-loop 'G domain'
G domain is common protein domain across many GTPases
